author: By Claire Moses
title: A Grocery Chain Just Fired Its Self-Checkouts
description: They’re bringing the humans back.
content: When it comes to grocery shopping, there seem to be two kinds of people in this world: those who prefer self-checkout, and those who prefer interaction with a human.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Liberal Donor Group Targets New York and California House Seats for 2024
description: The Democracy Alliance looks to two large blue states — with $10 million aimed at New York alone — as a way for Democrats to retake control of the House.
content: The Democracy Alliance, a powerful network of major liberal donors, will prioritize winning back control of the House for Democrats next year by planning to pour funds into crucial races in New York and California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Letters With Suspicious Substances Sent to Election Offices Spur Alarm
description: Letters, some apparently containing fentanyl or other substances, were sent to local election offices in at least four states.
content: Suspicious letters were sent to local elections officials in at least four states, the authorities said on Thursday, including to two locations in Washington State that were said to include white powders containing the toxic drug fentanyl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Howard
title: The Little Match Girl Lives to Tell the Tale
description: Two new middle grade novels insist Hans Christian Andersen got it all wrong.
content: One might think Hans Christian Andersen’s “The Little Match Girl,” an 1845 tear-jerker about a poverty-stricken child who freezes to death one snowy New Year’s Eve, would be a hard sell for today’s kids. But the sad tale and its author get a second chance in two new middle grade novels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle
title: Apple Co-Founder Steve Wozniak Is ‘Doing Good’ After Minor Stroke
description: The technology pioneer said he was back home in California after a brief stay in a Mexico City hospital.
content: When Steve Wozniak, the co-founder of Apple, suffered a dizzy spell on Wednesday, he took a precautionary trip to the hospital and learned that he had suffered a minor stroke. A day later, he said in an interview, the hospital released him and he was “doing good.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Why the Bronx Voted Republican for the First Time in a Generation
description: Was the Democratic incumbent — called the ‘Benedict Arnold’ of Throgs Neck in an ad — punished for allowing new construction?
content: Even in New York, where so many people pride themselves on their political engagement, hyperlocal elections rarely generate much interest either in terms of buzz or turnout, and they lead to surprising results even less often. But a City Council race on Tuesday managed to bring uncommon suspense. By Wednesday the contest had been called in favor of an X-ray technician who became the first Republican to win public office in the Bronx in nearly 20 years, a place where Democrats outnumber Republicans by more than 10 to 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Ewing
title: A Fumbled First Kiss and the Encouragement of a Stranger
description: For Daniel Andrew, the third date with Monica Pastor was the charm.
content: In 2019, Daniel Kneip Andrew made a deal with himself. He was between law school and his new job at a law firm and he decided to go on five dates. He had some time on his hands and would soon be busy. But after four lackluster meetings, his “expectations were at the lowest point,” Mr. Andrew said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: Democrats: You Can Chill Out Now!
description: Despite his bad poll numbers, I see a path to victory for Biden.
content: Well, this week has been an emotional roller coaster. On Sunday, a New York Times/Siena College poll showed President Biden behind Donald Trump in a bunch of battleground states, sending Democrats into a tizzy. Then on Tuesday, voters handed Democrats a string of election victories — the kind they have enjoyed in election after election since Trump was inaugurated in 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Yellen Says U.S. Wants ‘Healthy’ Economic Ties With China
description: The Treasury secretary said she had pressed her Chinese counterpart on China’s export controls and cautioned against supporting Russia.
content: The United States and China agreed on Friday that they would not seek to “decouple” their economies and pledged to take steps to improve the business climates for American and Chinese companies operating in both countries, a significant step toward thawing relations between the world’s largest economies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Yoshida
title: Sofia Coppola and All the Sad Girls
description: The film director helped populate the Internet with sad girls and elevate the cultural allure of feminine ennui. Has she put pop culture in a gilded cage?
content: For 25 years, Sofia Coppola’s films have served as a stylistic manual for how to be sad, or at least disaffected, in our modern age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Judge Puts Off Decision on Whether to Delay Trump Documents Trial
description: Judge Aileen M. Cannon said she would meet with prosecutors and defense lawyers in March to settle on a schedule for the former president’s trial in federal court in Florida.
content: A federal judge on Friday put off until at least March the fraught and consequential decision of whether to delay the start of former President Donald J. Trump’s trial on charges of illegally holding on to a trove of highly classified national security secrets after he left office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Conservative Thinkers Didn’t Create Trumpism
description: But Trumpism recreated them.
content: There is a story that professional ideamongers like to tell about political history that gives pride of place to their own work. It’s a story that usually begins with some small tribe of writers or intellectuals who come up with a set of theories that describe the world in a new way. Marginal at first, their arguments eventually break out into the wider sphere of campaigns and candidates, capturing one or the other major political coalition and finally emerging as the consensus of an age.
source.name: The New York Times

title: PinkPantheress Leaves the Bedroom for the Wider Pop World
description: A conversation about the 22-year-old singer, songwriter and producer’s new album and the art of sampling.
content: The British producer, singer and songwriter PinkPantheress, 22, emerged during the pandemic with a hushed and nostalgic play on dance music, turning canny samples from the club and beyond into intimate, original bedroom pop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Weekender
description: A national surge in drive-throughs, an interview with Barbra Streisand and a beginner’s guide to looking at the universe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Ackerberg
title: The Literary Lives of New York City’s Youth
description: Archival photos of children’s reading rooms at the New York Public Library over the years.
content: In 1906, Anne Carroll Moore was anointed the first head of the Department of Work With Children at the New York Public Library. There she oversaw the creation of the Central Children’s Room at the newly built flagship on 42nd Street and Fifth Avenue, established story hours and opened the previously locked shelves to all children provided they agreed to sign a pledge that read: “When I write my name in this book I promise to take good care of the books I use in the Library and at home, and to obey the rules of the Library.” By 1913, one third of the titles borrowed from all branches of the N.Y.P.L. were children’s books. To celebrate this year’s Best Illustrated Children’s Books, we looked through archival photos of the library’s children’s reading rooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb and Melina Delkic
title: After a Scare, Croatian Authorities Declare Coca-Cola Products Safe
description: After worries that a man had been sickened by his soft drink, the authorities said that it was an isolated incident and not a cause for wider concern.
content: Coca-Cola brand beverages have been deemed safe to drink in Croatia, government officials said on Thursday, following illnesses in the country that had raised fears that the bottles had been contaminated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Omer Bartov
title: What I Believe as a Historian of Genocide
description: We know from history that it is crucial to warn of the potential for genocide beforehand rather than condemn it afterward. We still have that time.
content: Israeli military operations have created an untenable humanitarian crisis, which will only worsen over time. But are Israel’s actions — as the nation’s opponents argue — verging on ethnic cleansing or, most explosively, genocide?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Catie Edmondson
title: Alarmed by Off-Year Losses, Mainstream Republicans Balk at Abortion Curbs
description: Worried about alienating critical blocs of voters, House Republicans from competitive districts are digging in against using spending bills for abortion and contraception restrictions.
content: Two days after Republicans across the country suffered a drubbing, dragged down by their opposition to abortion rights in the off-year elections, G.O.P. leaders on Capitol Hill appeared not to have gotten the memo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: The Village Home of George Lois, Visionary Adman, Is Listed for $6 Million
description: Mr. Lois, who died in 2022, combined two apartments at the Butterfield House in the early 1960s with his wife, Rosemary, who predeceased him by two months.
content: In the early 1960s, as his career as an art director and graphic designer was taking off, George Lois and his wife, Rosemary, set out to find a larger home for their expanding family. The two ultimately fell in love with the brand-new Butterfield House in Greenwich Village, so much so that they ended up buying two apartments there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Maggie Haberman
title: After Trump Testifies, Republicans Attack Judge in Civil Fraud Trial
description: Justice Arthur Engoron imposed a narrow gag order on Donald Trump. Right-wing allies are going after the judge on his behalf, through official channels and online.
content: Representative Elise Stefanik, a member of the House Republican leadership and an ally of former President Donald J. Trump, filed an ethics complaint Friday attacking the judge presiding over Mr. Trump’s civil fraud trial, the latest salvo in a right-wing war against the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The G.O.P’s Culture War Shtick Is Wearing Thin With Voters
description: It is an approach that repels and alienates far more than it persuades.
content: The Republican Party has always leaned on culture war issues to win elections, but for the past three years, since Joe Biden won office in 2020, an aggressive and virulent form of culture war demagoguery has been at the center of Republican political strategy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel, Selam Gebrekidan and John Eligon
title: Deadly Fire in Africa’s Richest City Exposed a Secret in Plain Sight
description: Officials blame immigrants and liberal housing laws, but a Times investigation found the entrenched problems that turned downtown Johannesburg into a blighted tinderbox.
content: Days after the fire, officials in Johannesburg reached for a well-worn script. They gathered the media for a made-for-television police raid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender and Shane Goldmacher
title: With Manchin Out, Democrats’ Path to Holding the Senate Is Narrow
description: While the party will be on defense in every competitive race, Republicans face some messy primaries and a recent history of nominating extreme candidates who have lost key contests.
content: Senator Joe Manchin III said he decided to forgo re-election because he’d accomplished all his goals. But for the Democrats he’s leaving behind in Washington, the work to hold the party’s already slim Senate majority is just beginning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Jonathan Weisman
title: Joe Manchin’s Retirement Adds Fuel to 2024 Rumors
description: The West Virginia senator, who announced Thursday that he would not seek re-election, has stoked chatter about a third-party run. But his allies have been tight-lipped about his plans.
content: Almost since he arrived in Washington, Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia has complained about the partisan nature of the Capitol and insisted that Americans aren’t as politically divided as the people they send to Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cat Marnell
title: The Window Treatments to the Soul
description: In her perceptive cultural history, “Eyeliner,” Zahra Hankir shows that liquid versus pencil is only the beginning.
content: In August 2014, I was drinking alone in North London. I Googled an address, then climbed into a cab and gave it to the driver: 30 Camden Square. The car pulled up to a four-story home in a leafy neighborhood, and I immediately felt embarrassed by my macabre mission. But I’d come this far. I got out of the car. The house where Amy Winehouse had died three years earlier was behind a black fence and a white wall. Across the street, there was a clearing with a tree, where a memorial collection had accumulated: photos of the beloved jazz-pop singer, flowers, candles, whiskey bottles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: U.K. Economy Stagnates as High Interest Rates Take Toll
description: The British economy flatlined in the third quarter, entering what is expected to be a protracted period of stagnation.
content: The British economy flatlined in the third quarter, entering what is expected to be a protracted period of stagnation on the cusp of a recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: A Reconnection, Long Distance and Then a Death Bed Wedding
description: Michaela Cook, an Australian pop-country singer known as Micks, and Jake Moyle found their way back to each other after losing touch. Soon, they were inseparable.
content: At one time, Michaela Elizabeth Cook and Jake Christopher Moyle were such close friends that he helped her choose her stage name as a singer, Micks. Even then, they would go on to lose touch for two years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: President’s War Against ‘Fake News’ Raises Alarms in South Korea
description: He calls fake news an enemy that threatens democracy. Critics of President Yoon Suk Yeol say he is silencing journalists in the name of fighting disinformation.
content: Allies of President Yoon Suk Yeol are attacking what they see as an existential threat to South Korea, and they are mincing few words. The head of Mr. Yoon’s party has called for the death sentence for a case of “high treason.” The culture ministry has vowed to root out what it called an “organized and dirty” conspiracy to undermine the country’s democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanne Timmons
title: How the T. Rex Built Up That Bone-Crushing Bite
description: An analysis of nine species of tyrannosaurs documented the evolutionary forces that led to the dinosaur’s reign.
content: If you have ever stood in the presence of a complete fossil of a Tyrannosaurus rex, there is no doubt it was the apex predator of its era. The adults were enormous, with giant skulls and banana-size serrated teeth. The strength of the bite of a full-grown T. rex has been the subject of numerous scientific studies, but mysteries endure about what led to this powerful chomp that ruled the end of the dinosaur era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Hidden Demon Uncovered in 18th-Century Painting
description: “The Death of Cardinal Beaufort” by Sir Joshua Reynolds was originally maligned for its depiction of a fanged figure, which was later painted over.
content: “The Death of Cardinal Beaufort,” a painting by Sir Joshua Reynolds depicting a scene from Shakespeare’s play “Henry VI, Part 2,” stirred controversy when it was first shown in 1789, because of a demon that lurked in its shadows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Lara Parker, a Memorable Witch on ‘Dark Shadows,’ Dies at 84
description: Her three-dimensional portrayal of a character who was also a vampire helped the Gothic soap opera develop a cult following.
content: Lara Parker, who found small-screen fame in the 1960s and ’70s as a beguiling and vengeful witch on the popular Gothic soap opera “Dark Shadows,” died on Oct. 12 at her home in Topanga, Calif. She was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: Surviving the Holidays at Work When You Dread the Season
description: Just because you’re not feeling festive doesn’t make you the office Grinch.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: Deforestation in the Brazilian Amazon Falls to a Five-Year Low
description: Tree loss was down 20 percent from the previous year, the environment minister announced.
content: Deforestation in the Amazon rainforest in Brazil fell to a five-year low, the country’s National Institute of Space Research announced on Thursday, a sign that Brazil, which has the biggest share of tropical forest in the world, was making progress on its pledge to halt all deforestation by the end of the decade.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 12 Grammy Nominees You Need to Hear
description: Some of the best competitions are the under-the-radar ones. Listen to nominated songs by Bettye LaVette, Molly Tuttle, Tainy and more.
content: I’m Jon Pareles, sitting in for Lindsay this week because while she’s on vacation, we couldn’t let the Grammy Awards nominations go by without a playlist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: A Buttermilk-Brined Chicken in Advance of the Big Bird
description: With roasted brussels sprouts and Ina Garten’s lemony puréed potatoes, it’s a nice warm-up for Turkey Day.
content: Good morning. Two weeks from today Thanksgiving will be a memory, so it’s definitely not too early to start your planning for the feast. Order your bird this weekend (birds, in my case). Sketch out a menu with the aid of our Thanksgiving recipe guide. Take an inventory of plates and platters, serving spoons, glasses, knives, forks and napkins. And consider the book of the rules.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Success of Rebecca Yarros and Barbra Streisand’s Mammoth Memoir
description: Alexandra Alter talks about her profile of the best-selling author behind “Fourth Wing” and Alexandra Jacobs discusses her review of “My Name is Barbra.”
content: It’s dueling Alexandras on this week’s Book Review podcast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: Davide Renne, Moschino Creative Director, Dead at 46
description: The Italian fashion designer died in Milan this week, just nine days after joining the famed Italian fashion house.
content: Davide Renne, the Italian fashion designer and former head of women’s wear at Gucci, died on Friday in Milan, Italy, nine days after becoming the creative director of Moschino. He was 46.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurtis Lee
title: After Averting a Hotel Strike, Las Vegas Still Has a Lot of Work to Do
description: Two big unions reached contract agreements with the three largest resort operators ahead of a series of events crucial to the city’s economic rebound.
content: Debra Jefferies, a cocktail waitress at the Horseshoe Las Vegas, spent much of the week wondering whether she would be walking a picket line, as she did in 1984 — the last time there was a major strike among hospitality workers in the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Britain’s Prisons Are Dangerously Close to Capacity
description: In England and Wales, prisons are almost full, part of a troubling trend that experts say creates unsafe conditions for both those in detention and the staff who manage them.
content: The prison system in England and Wales is dangerously close to capacity, with 98 percent of available spaces full, according to data released by Britain’s Ministry of Justice on Friday that experts said underscored an ongoing crisis within the criminal justice system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Israel Agrees to Short Pauses in Gaza Fighting, and More
description: Plus, Joe Manchin’s retirement fuels 2024 rumors, and House Republicans clash over spending.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Rugs That Ripple Like a Stream
description: Plus: a taste for beeswax, rare soaps and more from T’s cultural compendium.
content: The fashion designer Marco Zanini’s mother is Swedish, but growing up in his father’s native Italy, he never gave his Nordic roots much thought. It wasn’t until he turned 30 that he “became passionate about anything Scandinavian,” says the Milan-based 52-year-old, who served as the creative director of Halston, Rochas and Schiaparelli before launching his namesake ready-to-wear brand in 2019. “I started to spend my summers there, digging into anything that felt and looked Swedish.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Bonier
title: American Elections Are About Abortion Now
description: This week’s electoral victories for abortion rights offer lessons ahead of next November.
content: With two election cycles after the decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization under our belts, it cannot be denied: Abortion rights are the dominant issue in American politics. And when supporters of abortion rights — a clear majority of Americans — see a connection between their votes and protecting what was once guaranteed by Roe v. Wade, they are more likely to vote.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Debate Over the Value of the Humanities
description: Readers discuss the value of liberal arts as some universities cut programs. Also: Barbra Streisand’s new memoir.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mac Barnett
title: Mac Barnett Has ‘Nothing’ to Talk About
description: From mouse holes and doughnut holes to a world without night, these five picture books have it all.
content: Five new picture books all contemplate nothingness. From emptiness to absence to an intangible rhinoceros, we have a whole lot of nothing to discuss, so let’s get to it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Wall
title: Celebrating a Marriage and ‘a Second Chance at Life’
description: When Adam Jankelowitz was 2, he received a liver transplant. Decades later, he finally got to thank the donor’s parents in person — at his wedding with Jill Schreider.
content: Neither Jill Meredith Schreider nor Adam Jesse Jankelowitz drinks much alcohol — if any. But on their first date, both were too polite to interrupt the server’s lengthy presentation about the restaurant’s four-page tequila menu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Douglas Main
title: An Expedition Finds a ‘Lost’ Mammal and a Shrimp That Lives in Trees
description: In the Cyclops Mountains in the Indonesian part of the island of New Guinea, Oxford scientists and local guides made a series of spectacular discoveries.
content: A scientific expedition to a treacherous mountain range on the island of New Guinea has collected the first-ever photographic evidence confirming the survival of a bizarre, egg-laying mammal. The team also found dozens of undescribed species of insects, as well as newfound arachnids, amphibians and even a shrimp that dwells in trees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong
title: Suspect in Jan. 6 Capitol Attack Surrenders After Two-Day Manhunt
description: Gregory Yetman, who has been charged in the Jan. 6 attack, surrendered on Friday after fleeing the authorities serving him an arrest warrant.
content: Gregory Yetman, a former member of the New Jersey Army National Guard, surrendered to the authorities on Friday on charges related to the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol, concluding an intense manhunt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hajjar
title: The Egyptian Rapper Wegz Wants to Take Arabic Hip-Hop Worldwide
description: The 25-year-old has become a streaming star without releasing a full album. He just wrapped his first shows in the United States, and hopes to take his music even further.
content: On the ninth stop of his first world tour, the Egyptian rapper Wegz finished soundcheck at the Howard Theater in Washington, D.C., and relaxed on a worn black leather couch wearing a gray Carhartt fleece jacket and cream New Balance 990 sneakers. In his unflashy attire, passers-by might not have recognized one of the biggest artists in the emerging Arabic music scene calmly awaiting his set time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: Rebels Are Notching Key Wins Against the Military Junta in Myanmar
description: An offensive by an alliance of armed ethnic groups based in the north has seized key towns, galvanized groups elsewhere and spotlighted the military’s weakness.
content: An alliance of rebel forces in war-torn Myanmar has taken several key towns from the country’s military regime in recent weeks, the most successful challenge to the junta that seized power in a coup in 2021 and the latest evidence of how overstretched the military has become.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Genevieve Glatsky
title: A Treasure May Be Off the Coast of Colombia, but Who Can Claim It?
description: The San José galleon was destroyed in 1708, sinking with goods now worth billions. Colombia’s government is planning a recovery, but not everyone wants to see the shipwreck brought to the surface.
content: When the San José made its final voyage from Seville, Spain, to the Americas in 1706, the Spanish galleon was considered to be one of the most complex machines ever built.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: A Lean and Hungry Look
description: Kate Hawkins gives us a run for our money.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Hickley
title: Swiss Museum in Financial Straits Sells Three Cézannes for $53 Million
description: Museum Langmatt said the sales were necessary to keep its doors open. Critics had said they violated industry guidelines on when a museum should sell off parts of its collection.
content: Three paintings by Paul Cézanne that a Swiss museum foundation said it had to sell to ward off insolvency fetched $52.5 million, with buyer’s fees, at a Christie’s auction in New York last night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: Personalized A.I. Agents Are Here. Is the World Ready for Them?
description: The age of autonomous A.I. assistants could have huge implications.
content: You could think of the recent history of A.I. chatbots as having two distinct phases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer, Jazmine Ulloa and Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: As Haley Rises, the Clock Is Ticking on Taking Down Trump
description: Her latest debate performance prompted more than $1 million in donations — and drew in Ray Hunt, a billionaire backer. She’s still banking on a breakthrough to catch up to the front-runner.
content: In the Republican nomination contest, even five-inch stilettos might not be enough to overcome the towering figure of Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: For Max Beckmann, Art’s Ironist, Crisis and Rediscovery
description: A real vigor emerges in this exhibition at the Neue Galerie, which focuses on the painter’s unflinching Weimar scenes.
content: Before the war (the First World War, I mean; with so many wars one can lose count), Max Beckmann was painting clean, traditionalist self-portraits and lush pictures of bathers by the sea. He was a neoconservative with no time for Matisse or Picasso, and certainly no interest in the coming of abstraction. Then, when the war broke out, the artist volunteered for the medical corps of the Imperial German Army. He got posted to Flanders, where he witnessed the murderous, meaningless second Battle of Ypres. He sketched the Belgian landscape, and the doctors and orderlies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include an evil void, an unshakable sniper and a delightfully demonic cable box.
content: Oh man, how to describe Guillaume Nicloux’s profoundly despairing film. “The Mist” meets “Yellowjackets”? Close, but not sinister enough. I’ll just say this: The movie crushed me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Satow
title: Welcome to Hochatown, the Town Created by Airbnb
description: In a rural corner of Oklahoma, rustic cabins have been replaced by $1 million rental homes. But even as Airbnb reports record profits, the boom has softened. What will that mean for hosts?
content: The tiny town of Hochatown, on the shores of Broken Bow Lake in the southeast corner of Oklahoma, was created exactly one year ago. And it’s almost entirely thanks to Airbnb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: What History Tells Us About the Feel-Bad Economy
description: Why are voters unhappy about low unemployment and falling inflation?
content: Since Tuesday’s big Democratic electoral victories, I’ve been seeing some speculation to the effect that the 2024 election may be marked by a reverse coattail effect: that President Biden, whose poll numbers have supposedly been weighed down by a bad economy, may be lifted up by local candidates who have been racking up wins over social issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy and Camille Baker
title: Intense Protests Again Shut Down Midtown Manhattan Streets
description: Protesters marched at campuses and through Midtown on Thursday as anger and fear over the war in the Middle East escalated.
content: Thousands of pro-Palestinian protesters calling for a cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas war shut down traffic in Midtown Manhattan on Thursday night, marking one of the largest actions in New York City in recent weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Crocodile Bites Man. Man Bites Back.
description: A surprising tale of Northern Territory chutzpah.
content: It was a story that seemed almost too Australian to be true: The incredible tale of a crocodile attack, foiled by the gnashing of the victim’s jaws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: Germany’s Stifling of Pro-Palestinian Voices Pits Historical Guilt Against Free Speech
description: The country’s authorities have banned many protests in the name of fighting antisemitism. Critics say such restrictions are discriminatory.
content: Since fleeing Syria a decade ago, Wafa Mustafa has spoken out for political prisoners at the United Nations, held vigils outside war crimes trials and chanted in solidarity with Iranians protesting their authoritarian government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Rabbis From Across the Globe Flock to New York for Prayer — and Hope
description: Participants in an annual conference of rabbis visited the burial place of the spiritual leader of the Chabad-Lubavitch movement.
content: The rabbis came from Israel and Ukraine, from Azerbaijan and France, from Thailand and farther still, as thousands of Jews filed into a graveyard in Queens under a sea of black hats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Gonorrhea Is Becoming Drug Resistant. Scientists Just Found a Solution.
description: A new antibiotic, zoliflodacin, is as effective as the current standard of care. Its creation may hasten the arrival of other needed antibiotics.
content: A new antibiotic, the first to be developed in decades, can cure gonorrhea infections at least as effectively as the most powerful current treatment, a large clinical trial has found. The drug, zoliflodacin, is taken as a single dose, and it has not yet been approved for use in any country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Thousands Wait at Ukraine Border After Polish Truckers Blockade It
description: As drivers protested what they say is unfair competition from their Ukrainian counterparts, the waiting time at one checkpoint was estimated to be seven days.
content: Thousands of trucks were lined up at several border crossings between Ukraine and Poland on Friday, preventing goods from being delivered to Europe and causing traffic jams lasting several days as Polish truckers blocked checkpoints over what they said was unfair competition from their Ukrainian counterparts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Della Volpe and Phoebe Lett
title: I’m a Pollster. Democrats Need Young Voters to Win in 2024.
description: Gen Z and millennials aren’t hot on Biden — or government generally. But the Democrats can win them back.
content: Well before the latest Times/Siena poll raised concerns about Joe Biden’s re-election prospects, John Della Volpe was sounding alarms. The Harvard Kennedy School pollster — who worked on Biden’s 2020 campaign — first noticed a change in the way young voters were thinking about politics last spring. For months he has heard dissatisfaction with the two parties and increasing attraction to third party options from young voters in his town halls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Man vs. Musk: A Whistleblower Creates Headaches for Tesla
description: An employee who was fired after expressing safety concerns leaked personnel records and sensitive data about driver-assistance software.
content: A day after Lukasz Krupski put out a fire at a Tesla car delivery location in Norway, seriously burning his hands and preventing a disaster, he got an email from Elon Musk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Chris Christie to Travel to Israel
description: The trip will be his second to a war zone since opening his presidential bid.
content: Chris Christie, the former governor of New Jersey who is running for president, will go to Israel on Sunday, pressing what he sees as his foreign policy advantage in the race and challenging the other Republicans seeking the White House nomination to join him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Farrell and Emli Bendixen
title: A Garden Shed Becomes a Retreat Filled With Treasures
description: At the far end of her London yard, a British interior designer has created a richly adorned work space.
content: The window of the British interior designer Tamsin Saunders’s childhood bedroom looked out onto the South Downs, the rolling hills that culminate abruptly in steep chalk cliffs along England’s southeast coast. The landscape’s rugged beauty instilled in her an affinity for the patterns and textures of the natural world. She spent her early years in the nearby forests, collecting fossils and gathering fragments of wood to decorate with paint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: Lahaina’s Immigrants Weigh an Uncertain Future
description: Consumed by loss after the August wildfire, many immigrants who have made the historic town their home wonder if they will have to move.
content: It was a nice life, and by the sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: ‘Is This Hell?’ The Pilot Accused of Trying to Crash a Plane Tells His Story.
description: Joseph Emerson, charged with attempted murder, said he felt trapped in a dream after taking mushrooms. He had feared mental health treatments that could disrupt his career.
content: In the minutes before he boarded an Alaska Airlines flight home last month, Joseph Emerson, a pilot for the airline, texted his wife. He was eager to be home with their two young children and longing to be next to her. “I just want to hold you,” he wrote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: Israel’s Ticking Clock
description: The country has slowed down to protect its troops and consult allies. But as outrage over the war grows, it’s running out of time to defeat Hamas.
content: The invasion seemed imminent. In the hours after Hamas attacked Israel on Oct. 7, Benjamin Netanyahu appeared ready to send his troops storming into Gaza. Instead, he chose a different strategy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olivia Craighead
title: Listen to a Wellness-Culture Satire That Delves a Few Levels Deeper
description: In Jessie Gaynor’s debut novel, “The Glow,” read by Gabra Zackman, a P.R. rep immerses herself in the woo-woo world of a cultlike “spiritual retreat,” and its enigmatic leader.
content: In a last-ditch effort to impress her boss and not get fired from her public relations job — and to keep chipping away at an overwhelming medical debt — Jane attends a woo-woo wellness retreat in order to bag its enigmatic leader, Cass, as a new client. She’s warned that this retreat may be a cult, but maybe this cult could bring in a lot of money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Curtains Down, Bottoms Up: When the Show Ends, the Night’s Just Getting Started
description: “Dead Letter No. 9,” “Cocktail Magique” and “Hypnotique” are offering theatergoers a taste of nightlife.
content: A funny thing happened at Dead Letter No. 9, a new performance space in Brooklyn. It was just after 10 p.m. on a Saturday in late October. The evening’s show had finished, but the audience wouldn’t leave — crowding instead into the adjoining bar for cocktails, mocktails and flatbreads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: SZA, ‘Barbie’ Songs and Young Women Lead 2024 Grammy Nominees
description: The indie-rock group boygenius, Olivia Rodrigo, Taylor Swift and Victoria Monét are among the most nominated artists for the 66th annual awards in February.
content: SZA, Taylor Swift, Olivia Rodrigo, the indie supergroup boygenius and the eclectic bandleader Jon Batiste are among the top nominees for the 66th annual Grammy Awards, leading a class of contenders dominated by young women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum, Dana Rubinstein and Michael Rothfeld
title: F.B.I. Seizes Eric Adams’s Phones as Campaign Investigation Intensifies
description: Days after a raid at Mr. Adams’s chief fund-raiser’s home, federal agents took the mayor’s phones and iPad, two people with knowledge of the matter said.
content: F.B.I. agents seized Mayor Eric Adams’s electronic devices early this week in what appeared to be a dramatic escalation of a criminal inquiry into whether his 2021 campaign conspired with the Turkish government and others to funnel money into its coffers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Vowel-less Crossword
description: Ryan McCarty throws everything but the kitchen sink at us, or rather the ktchn snk.
content: VOWEL-LESS CROSSWORD — This kind of puzzle is growing on me, and today’s grid is extra alluring because of its constructor. Ryan McCarty regularly creates gnarly Saturday crosswords but has never before ventured into the weird world of variety puzzles. The vowel-less crosswords are strange enough that I find myself giggling when I solve one; I can’t help but imagine someone looking over my shoulder at a jumbled sea of consonants, for starters. I also find myself counting letters on my fingers throughout and becoming lost in the process, which is a bit humbling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Greenblatt
title: Making a Murderer, David Fincher Style
description: With “The Killer,” how to build an oddball executioner in seven easy steps.
content: Movie assassins tend to move through the world like chic land sharks: sleek, ruthless, undetectable until it’s too late. But the numerous quirks of the nameless lead portrayed by Michael Fassbender in David Fincher’s latest film, “The Killer” (streaming on Netflix) defy the genre stereotypes of a suave, soulless hit man. Instead, the screenwriter Andrew Kevin Walker, adapting from a French graphic novel series by Alexis Nolent, said via Zoom that he deliberately designed his bucket-hat-wearing, McMuffin-eating muse as “the anti-James Bond, almost alien.” He added, “The fact that he doesn’t care whether his drink is shaken or stirred makes sense for his character. We wanted him to hide in plain sight.” Below, how to build an oddball executioner in seven easy steps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: ‘Timepiece Gentleman’ Swindled Customers Out of $3 Million, U.S. Says
description: Anthony Farrer, 35, who ran a consignment store in Beverly Hills, used money from the sale of customers’ luxury watches to finance a lavish lifestyle for himself, federal prosecutors said.
content: The businessman collected the luxury watches from customers, promising them that he would sell the watches on consignment and take no more than a 5 percent fee, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan McKinney
title: Nothing Could Happen Between Us
description: We only had a few weeks together. Why did that allow us to fall so hard so fast?
content: Last year, two days before my 29th birthday, I slipped on ice at the restaurant where I worked and sprained my ankle. Told to stay home and recover, I quickly grew bored and did what any single person with sudden downtime would do — re-downloaded my dating apps. Within 24 hours, I matched with Motorcycle Man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Rachel Cohn, Jen Poyant, Chris Wood, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto and Dan Powell
title: Personalized GPTs Are Here, F.T.C. Chair Lina Khan on A.I. Competition, and Mayhem at Apefest
description: “On this podcast, we’re automating the haters.”
content: Warning: this episode contains some explicit language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller, Aaron Boxerman, Malachy Browne and Neil Collier
title: Gaza City Hospitals Are Caught in Deadly Crossfire
description: Battling Hamas fighters, Israeli forces are “closing in” on hospitals where thousands of people are stranded, while the chief U.S. diplomat says “far too many Palestinians have been killed.”
content: Gaza City’s hospitals were increasingly under siege on Friday, with hundreds of seriously ill and wounded patients and thousands of displaced people stranded on hospital grounds as intense, close-quarters combat between Israeli troops and Hamas fighters raged around them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: ‘The Curse’ Series Premiere Recap: The Cameras Are Rolling
description: Nathan Fielder is not playing himself for once but his core fascinations are still on display.
content: Nathan Fielder’s career to this point has been defined by an obsession with the way people act when they are being filmed. In his Comedy Central series, “Nathan for You,” he came up with outlandish ideas to promote small businesses, often capturing the surreality of human behavior as he instituted his plans. He followed that up with “The Rehearsal,” an HBO show in which he tested the idea that one could “rehearse” for real life scenarios — confrontations with friends or even parenthood — and filmed the results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Clare Toeniskoetter, Shannon Lin, Rikki Novetsky, Michael Benoist, Brendan Klinkenberg, Ben Calhoun, Dan Powell, Chelsea Daniel and Alyssa Moxley
title: What Adidas Knew About Kanye
description: The runaway success of the Yeezy collaboration came at a heavy price.
content: Warning: this episode contains some explicit language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Ocampo
title: A New York Reporter With a New Perspective
description: Luis Ferré-Sadurní’s plans took an unexpected turn when Gov. Kathy Hochul announced an impromptu trip to Israel last month.
content: On a warm Friday afternoon in October, Luis Ferré-Sadurní, who covers New York State politics for The New York Times, scanned the faces of a crowd at a beachfront resort in Puerto Rico. He had hoped to spot Robert Menendez, the New Jersey senator who had been indicted on federal bribery charges — and who was, nevertheless, holding his annual fund-raiser at the hotel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: In Israel, There Is Grief and There Is Fury. Beneath the Fury, Fear.
description: Israelis were shattered on Oct. 7. Can they recover?
content: I landed in Israel and went straight to a funeral.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica, Joe Coscarelli, Caryn Ganz and Jon Pareles
title: Grammy Snubs and Surprises: boygenius Thrives, Country and Rap Wither
description: A look at the Grammys’ most unexpected and interesting story lines, including Olivia Rodrigo’s intergenerational rock battle with the Rolling Stones.
content: Young women from across genres — along with the Recording Academy’s favorite polymath spoiler Jon Batiste — reigned atop the nominations on Friday for the 66th annual Grammy Awards, to be held Feb. 4 in Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Victoria Monét on Her 7 Grammy Nods (and One for Her Toddler)
description: The pop and R&B singer and songwriter has long aspired to be a solo star. Now she’s landed the second-most nominations this year, and is “trying to wrap my head around it.”
content: On the morning of this year’s Grammy Award nominations, Victoria Monét, the pop and R&B singer and songwriter, had the champagne ready no matter what.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Rice Krispie Treats in a Plastic Tube, and Other Dances
description: In her funny and fidgety way, the choreographer Michelle Ellsworth presents new works that probe the uses and limits of language and movement.
content: “I should try and solve some problems,” the artist Michelle Ellsworth said on Thursday at the Chocolate Factory Theater in Queens, as five dancers buzzed around a hulking wooden contraption that looked like a cross between a kitchen, a playground structure and an MRI machine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Marina Cicogna, Italy’s First Major Female Film Producer, Dies at 89
description: A countess from an influential Italian family, she charted her own course and produced films by the likes of Pasolini and Zeffirelli.
content: Marina Cicogna, an Italian countess who became her country’s first major female film producer, guiding to the screen celebrated films by Pier Paolo Pasolini, Franco Zeffirelli and Elio Petri, died on Nov. 4 at her home in Rome. She was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: How Tropical Birds Took Over This European Capital, Bringing a ‘Splash of Color’
description: After a small group of parakeets were released from a zoo in Brussels in the 1970s, their numbers soared. A population increase has also occurred across the continent.
content: In the lively Brussels neighborhood of Flagey, you can be sure of two things: People will be lined up for fries at Frit Flagey, and pigeons will be nearby, pecking at scraps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: U.S. Seeks to Resume Military Dialogue With Beijing
description: The Joint Chiefs chairman said in a letter to his Chinese counterpart that restoring communications was crucial to avoiding misunderstandings.
content: President Biden’s top military adviser has told China that the United States is open to resuming military-to-military communication that Beijing suspended last year to protest then-Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 10, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Nov. 10, 2023.
content: An article on Thursday about Danica Roem, the first transgender state senator in the South, misstated the type of meal program supported by Ms. Roem. It’s a universal free school one, not a universal preschool one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Bradley and Justin French
title: Black Folk Musicians Are Reclaiming the Genre
description: In returning to a songbook that is decades — if not centuries — old, a new generation of performers is expanding the definition of what their traditional art form can be.
content: TRAY WELLINGTON KNOWS that many will take the title of his 2022 album, “Black Banjo,” as an oxymoron. The banjo, and with it an entire body of folk-based music, is now so thoroughly associated with whiteness as to obscure its origins in Black musical tradition. “One of the first things I heard when I started playing banjo was, ‘You’re not supposed to be doing this,’” says Wellington, 24, whose father is Black and mother is white. But for him, playing the banjo has become an act of reclamation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: Review: With Premieres, an Orchestra Keeps Facing Forward
description: The American Composers Orchestra, which occupies an essential place in the New York scene, presented an evening of several new works at Zankel Hall.
content: Pity the American composer interested in writing orchestral music. Unless your last name is Glass, Reich or Adams, opportunities are destined to come few and far between.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy O'Neill
title: Debut Novels About Women Longing in Obsessive, Sometimes Uncanny Ways
description: A lonely Londoner cyber-stalks her married lover and his other paramours; a dispersed Guatemalan American family comes together in crisis; a Mohawk mother navigates life off the rez.
content: Sheena Patel’s I’M A FAN (Graywolf, 203 pp., paperback, $17) is an impolite novel about romantic obsession, set in a liberalized but inequitable sexual economy that rewards the white and rich. The unnamed narrator, a young brown woman living in London, spends much of the book online, fixating on the white, married and much older “man I want to be with” and the other women in his life. Imagining herself meeting one paramour in particular, she wonders, “Would I tell her I know who all her friends are and I watch their stories too, would I tell her I screenshot the photos she takes of herself and study her face so intently sometimes I fear I’ve picked up some facial expressions or tonal inflections from her?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Barron, Tina Antolini and Daniel Ramirez
title: Your New Music Mixtape
description: The Beatles, Megan Thee Stallion and more.
content: Jon Pareles, chief pop music critic for The New York Times, brings you a playlist of five recently released songs worth checking out:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: Antisemitic Hate Crimes Soar in New York City
description: Several high-profile incidents are being investigated as hate crimes in New York, where anti-Jewish incidents more than tripled in October compared with last year.
content: The police in New York City are searching for vandals who scrawled “Hamas” and antisemitic graffiti on several Upper East Side apartment buildings last month amid a sharp increase in hate crimes directed at the Jewish community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: boygenius on Its First Grammy Nominations and Keeping Rock Fun
description: Julien Baker, Phoebe Bridgers and Lucy Dacus earned six nods for their debut LP, “The Record.” Texts from fellow nominees Taylor Swift and Billie Eilish followed.
content: For boygenius, the indie-rock supergroup with a penchant for neckties and introspective songs, this fall has held the kind of firsts that prove a rock band has turned into a phenomenon: its first arena show at a Madison Square Garden packed with fans chanting every lyric, its first performance at the Hollywood Bowl, and soon, its first feature on “Saturday Night Live.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Higher Contribution Limits Are Coming for 401(k) Retirement Plans
description: But, financial advisers note, most people cannot afford to set aside the maximum amount. “This is a system geared for high earners,” one expert said.
content: Those with enough means will be able to save more money in their workplace retirement accounts next year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The 2023 New York Times/New York Public Library Best Illustrated Children’s Books
description: Take a peek at this year’s winners.
content: The 10 winners of The New York Times/New York Public Library Best Illustrated Children’s Books Award are chosen each year by a rotating panel of three expert judges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: What Israelis Fear the World Does Not Understand
description: The writer Yossi Klein Halevi talks about why many Israelis see the ongoing conflict as an “existential war.”
content: Earlier this week, we heard a Palestinian perspective on the conflict. Today, I wanted to have on an Israeli perspective.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Prince Harry Can Proceed With a Lawsuit Against Daily Mail Publisher
description: A judge rejected an attempt by the publisher to have Harry’s case thrown out, paving the way for the trial to move ahead.
content: Prince Harry and other celebrities can proceed with their case against The Daily Mail’s publisher, a British judge ruled on Friday, paving the way for a lengthy court battle over phone hacking and other alleged violations of privacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Alexandra Stevenson
title: Biden and Xi to Seek to Stabilize Relations in California Meeting
description: Taiwan, election interference and the war in the Middle East will be on the agenda, officials say. But the leaders will also look for ways to strengthen ties.
content: President Biden and President Xi Jinping of China plan to meet in California on Wednesday for a discussion that Mr. Biden’s advisers say is meant to stabilize relations even as it features a host of topics on which the two fiercely competitive countries disagree.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: The Betting on the Presidential Election Has Begun
description: While two leading prediction markets are fighting regulatory restrictions in court, wagers on politics and economics are still being made.
content: Financial journalists love Wall Street aphorisms. I use them whenever I can.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cindy Shmerler
title: Overlooked No More: Ángela Ruiz Robles, Inventor of an Early E-Reader
description: Long before Kindles and iPads became popular, Ruiz Robles, a teacher, created her Mechanical Encyclopedia to help lighten her students’ textbook load.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Yuhas
title: America’s top diplomat says ‘far too many Palestinians have been killed.’
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken’s comments were the latest indication that the Biden administration is increasingly concerned about the civilian death toll in Gaza.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Friday that “far too many Palestinians have been killed” in Gaza, in the latest indication that the Biden administration is growing increasingly concerned about the civilian death toll under Israel’s bombardment and ground invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Maya King
title: Kamala Harris Is Set to Visit South Carolina for Campaign Kickoff
description: The vice president is said to be planning a surprise Friday trip to file paperwork for the state’s primary, which will be the first party-approved voting of 2024.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris will travel to Columbia, S.C., on Friday to formally file President Biden’s paperwork to appear on the Democratic primary ballot in the state, according to two people familiar with her plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Friday Briefing
description: A push from the U.S. for Israel to curtail its bombardment of Gaza.
content: The Israeli military has limited time to carry out its operations in the Gaza Strip before anger among Arabs in the region and global frustration over the rising civilian death toll constrain Israel’s goal of eradicating Hamas, U.S. officials said this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Hold That Thought! Here’s Why Being Interrupted Is So Irritating.
description: Plus, a few things you can do about it.
content: My parents have been married for 60 years. At this point, they’ve worked out most of their issues. But if my father interrupts my mother, her eyes grow unnaturally bright, and she rises up like a cobra.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Marine Veteran, 91, Takes Joy in Building Model Ships
description: Raymond Daughtry Jr. served in the Korean War. A history buff, he has made model battleships including one of the U.S.S. Arizona, which was sunk at Pearl Harbor.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday, the federal holiday for Veterans Day. We’ll meet a 91-year-old Marine Corps veteran who builds model ships. We’ll also find out why Dr. Ruth Westheimer has just been named New York’s loneliness ambassador.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Megan Rapinoe, Emma Hayes and a Women’s Soccer Crossroads
description: Rapinoe, who helped define U.S. soccer for a decade, is retiring after this week’s N.W.S.L. final. Hayes, the Chelsea coach, will try to put her stamp on it next.
content: Emma Hayes first met Megan Rapinoe before she was Megan Rapinoe. Or, rather, just as she was becoming Megan Rapinoe. She was not yet a winner of two World Cups, not yet an Olympic champion, not yet captain of her country, not yet a powerful and urgent voice away from the field. Rapinoe was not even a professional soccer player back then, not quite.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Grammy Awards 2024: The Full List of Nominees
description: Artists, albums and songs competing for trophies at the 66th annual ceremony are being announced on Friday. The show will take place on Feb. 4 at Crypto.com Arena in Los Angeles.
content: SZA is the top nominee for the 66th annual Grammy Awards with nine nods, all for her album “SOS,” which topped the Billboard 200 for 10 weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Byron Wien, Wall Street Seer of the Unexpected, Dies at 90
description: A widely read financial analyst, he was known for his annual forecast “Ten Surprises.” But he was fallible, as when he predicted a President Hillary Clinton.
content: At age 80, Byron Wien compiled “20 Life Lessons” from a long career as a Wall Street soothsayer. “Never retire” was No. 20. “If you work forever, you can live forever,’’ he explained. “I know there is an abundance of biological evidence against this theory, but I’m going with it anyway.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan and Alisha Jucevic
title: The Greatest, and Sometimes Silliest, Love of All
description: Zeke Smith of “Survivor” and Nico Santos of “Superstore” describe themselves as “cartoon characters that live with one another.”
content: Before Ezekiel Oliver Smith and Michael Nicolas Briones Santos attended the GLAAD Media Awards in Los Angeles in April 2018, Mr. Smith enjoyed his time alone more than his time on dates. He loved his own company, and he had a strong community and a thriving social life. When he was alone, he never felt lonely, and he thought that maybe he was happiest when he was single.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Taylor Swift Takes Her Eras Tour Global, Shaking Argentina
description: The singer-songwriter began her Eras Tour outside North America, and some Swifties in Argentina camped out for more than five months.
content: On May 31, Florencia Romeo slept in a tent outside Argentina’s largest stadium with her girlfriend and her sister. They had heard rumors that Taylor Swift might be coming to Buenos Aires, and they wanted to be first in line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: I Earn Much More Than My Husband. Shouldn’t He Get a Better Job?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to address financial imbalances in a marriage.
content: I’ve been happily married for more than 10 years, and my husband is wonderful — he’s my best friend and a great partner in almost every respect. The only major issue is that, while I earn a relatively modest salary, I still make more than 80 percent of the household income and have done so for almost all of our time together, though I’ve never consented to this. He has a small business that he has never tried to properly expand, and because of where we live, he can only work remotely, which is not easy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Recaps the Worst of the G.O.P. Presidential Debate
description: “Oh, yeah, there was name-calling, wild rants and personal attacks. Even Trump was watching like, ‘Game recognize game,’” Jimmy Fallon said of the event.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: Before World Leaders Arrive, San Francisco Races to Clean Up
description: The Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation conference comes at a pivotal moment for the city as it struggles to rebound from the pandemic.
content: San Francisco had the air this week of teenagers frantically cleaning up after a house party with their parents on the way home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Hahn
title: Innocence, Here and Abroad
description: Taboos about what can’t be shown in picture books vary around the world.
content: One of the funniest books I know includes a spread illustrating some of the different positions in which a man and a woman can “fit together.” One configuration involves a space hopper, another a skateboard. Published in 1993, Babette Cole’s “Mummy Laid an Egg!” is a Where-do-babies-come-from? book for young kids that not only tells it like it is (space hopper and all), but also jokes about the outlandish fairy tales desperate parents use to avoid discussing something they really, really don’t want to talk about.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Rosenberg and Thomas Fuller
title: Street Battles Rage in Gaza City Ruins, as Residents Flee on Foot
description: The Biden administration, which has pressed Israel to do more to safeguard civilian lives, said Israel had agreed to steps to help people flee the northern Gaza Strip and receive aid.
content: Israeli soldiers and armored vehicles have engaged Hamas fighters in days of running gun battles in Gaza City, fighting through rubble-filled streets and blasted-out buildings for control of the Gaza Strip’s largest urban center and the militants’ main stronghold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Restrictions on L.G.B.T.Q. Depictions Rattle Hungary’s Cultural World
description: A government campaign against what it calls “homosexual propaganda” is unsettling booksellers and has resulted in the firing of the director of one of the country’s leading museums.
content: When a far-right member of Hungary’s Parliament invited the media three years ago to watch her shred a book of fairy tales that included a gay Cinderella, only one reporter showed up.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: No Regrets or What-Ifs, Just a Goal of Returning Georgetown to the Top
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 10, 2023.
content: “Never use the word ‘never.’ Never is forever, and that would be the mistake I made. Never comes back to haunt you.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Yossi Klein Halevi
description: The Nov. 10, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Yossi Klein Halevi. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Roy
title: TikTokers Mourn the Shutdown of Omegle
description: The popular video app was beloved for producing spontaneous encounters, which many content creators turned into followers and profits.
content: Romain Degrave first discovered Omegle three years ago, when he was still in high school. Since its inception in 2009, the online service, which randomly pairs strangers for anonymous video chat sessions, had been connecting users across the globe for moments of discovery, whimsy, cross-cultural exchange and political debate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: What Ended the Market Rally
description: A disappointing Treasury auction and hawkish comments by the Federal Reserve’s chair underscored investor fears about inflation.
content: The S&P 500 was on its way to a ninth straight day of gains on Thursday when investors got hit by a double whammy: a lackluster auction for 30-year Treasury bonds and more hawkish words from Jay Powell, the Fed chair, that prompted a sell-off in stocks and bonds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: Gadfly Lawyer for Gilgo Beach Families Courts Cameras and Tipsters
description: John Ray held news conferences championing the victims for years as law enforcement dragged its feet. Now, he’s a magnet for information.
content: It seemed like a classic John Ray news conference last month, with the flamboyant Long Island lawyer stepping up to news cameras, bedecked in a polka dot tie and matching fedora.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Pastor Indicted With Trump in Georgia Asks Evangelical Supporters for Help
description: The Rev. Stephen C. Lee says he was pastoring to people in Georgia after the 2020 election. The indictment says he was pressuring an elections worker.
content: The Rev. Stephen C. Lee is one of the lesser-known figures indicted with former President Donald J. Trump in Fulton County, Ga., on charges of unlawfully conspiring to keep Mr. Trump in power after the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Pittsburgh Museum Apologizes for Handling of Islamic Art Show
description: The Frick Pittsburgh, which postponed an exhibition featuring 10 centuries of Islamic art after the outbreak of the Israel-Hamas war, apologized for the offense its leader’s explanation caused.
content: The head of the Frick Pittsburgh apologized Thursday for the way she handled the postponement of an exhibition of Islamic art, which had been scheduled to open this month before museum leaders decided to delay it because of the Israel-Hamas war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Moody’s Changes U.S. Credit Outlook to ‘Negative’
description: Moody’s reaffirmed America’s credit rating at the highest AAA level but expressed concern about the nation’s fiscal trajectory amid congressional dysfunction.
content: The outlook on the credit rating of the United States was changed  to “negative” from “stable” on Friday by the ratings firm Moody’s, which pointed to the nation’s worsening fiscal position and political polarization as long-term concerns for America’s economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: He’s Gone From Miami, to Celebrity, to Upending Greek Politics
description: The rapid ascent of Stefanos Kasselakis, a former Goldman Sachs trader and Greece’s first openly gay party leader, has gripped the nation. But his leadership is dividing the country’s main opposition party.
content: Stefanos Kasselakis was virtually unknown in Greece just six months ago when he was a no-chance election candidate with Syriza, the country’s main opposition party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Solis
title: The Big Number: 98%
description: Shares in the co-working company WeWork had already fallen precipitously before it filed for bankruptcy.
content: Shares in the co-working company WeWork had already fallen precipitously before it filed for bankruptcy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: The Best of Late Night This Week
description: The hosts spent most of the week riffing on the third Republican debate, but also took time to discuss former President Trump’s lead over President Biden in an early poll. Here’s what they had to say.
content: The hosts spent most of the week riffing on the third Republican debate, but also took time to discuss former President Trump’s lead over President Biden in an early poll. Here’s what they had to say.

title: Three Stories of Pregnancy and Birth in Ukraine
description: One of the first sounds my son ever heard was an air siren. He is one of the lucky ones.
content: One of the first sounds my son ever heard was an air siren. He is one of the lucky ones.

author: By Marco Hernandez and Josh Holder
title: The Tunnels of Gaza
description: A maze of tunnels extends below the Gaza Strip, allowing Hamas fighters to stay out of sight and smuggle weapons and goods.
content: A maze of tunnels extends below the Gaza Strip, allowing Hamas fighters to stay out of sight and smuggle weapons and goods.

title: Blinken Stresses Need for Humanitarian Aid for Gaza
description: During a trip to New Delhi, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said that “far too many Palestinians have been killed” in Gaza.

title: This Is Our Music
description: The folk musicians Dom Flemons, Kara Jackson, Amythyst Kiah and Tray Wellington discuss the complications of being a Black performer working in a genre now commonly associated with whiteness.

description: On the steps of the New York Public Library, demonstrators waved flags and called for a cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas war.
